item.title: Gigabit Ethernet Port Scales WAN Bandwidth
item.description:
Upgrading your business internet bandwidth from copper to fiber or from OC-3 SONET can feel overwhelming. How much bandwidth should you commit to? An Ethernet port strategy provides flexibility and cost-efficiency for your future needs. Traditional telecom services lack scalability. Upgrading from a T1 to a T3 line or an OC-3 requires completely different interfaces, connectors, and even router changes. Each upgrade often means new hardware and potential service disruptions...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/gigabit-ethernet-port-scales-wan-bandwidth/

item.title: What Is a DS3 Circuit Or T3 Line?
item.description:
Businesses that need more bandwidth than a T1 line often choose DS3. This article explores DS3, its relationship to T3 lines, and competition from Ethernet over Copper. DS3, or Digital Signal level 3, follows standards set by Bell Labs for the telephone industry. The smallest unit, DS0, has a 64 Kbps bandwidth, enough for one digitized phone call using the original digital standard, PCM (Pulse Code Modulation). Combining 24 DS0s creates a DS1, which runs on a T1 line...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/what-is-a-ds3-circuit-or-t3-line/

item.title: T1, T3 and Ethernet Bandwidth
item.description:
By: John Shepler When upgrading your business internet, you have several high-performance options available, including T1 lines, T3 (DS3) lines, and Ethernet options delivered via copper or fiber optic cables. T1 Lines T1 lines have been a reliable business internet solution for decades. While their use has become more specialized, they remain a strong option, especially in areas without many choices. The primary advantage of T1 lines is their reliance on existing copper telephone wiring, making them accessible in locations with standard landline service...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/t1-t3-and-ethernet-bandwidth/

item.title: Ethernet Better Than a T3 Line
item.description:
By: John Shepler T3 voice and data lines, once a reliable option for businesses, now offer insufficient speed (45 Mbps) for modern demands, which often exceed 100 Mbps. Businesses today require significantly faster connections, with some even seeking speeds beyond 10 Gbps. If you’re still using a T3 line, you might find better bandwidth options at a similar or lower cost. What is a T3 Line? Developed by Bell Labs, the T3 line was designed to carry numerous simultaneous phone conversations, a function it still serves in certain settings...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/ethernet-better-than-a-t3-line/

item.title: DS3 and Fractional DS3 Broadband
item.description:
Companies seeking to increase bandwidth often consider DS3 bandwidth service. This article explains DS3 and other technologies that provide similar mid-level bandwidth. DS3, or Digital Signal 3, is a standardized telecom service that uses TDM (Time-Division Multiplexing) technology. To clarify, the fundamental unit is DS0 at 64 Kbps, representing a single digitized phone call. DS1, bundling 24 DS0 channels, operates at 1.5 Mbps and is commonly known as a T1 line...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/ds3-and-fractional-ds3-broadband/

item.title: D3 vs DS3 Bandwidth Choices
item.description:
For a long time, mid-size and large businesses have relied on DS3 services to fulfill their broadband internet needs. However, a new contender has emerged, aiming to either complement or even replace the well-established DS3 connection. ](http://www.megatrunks.com/) If your business requires more bandwidth than what bonded T1 lines can provide, you’re likely familiar with DS3. But how about D3? D3 stands for DOCSIS 3.0, a cable broadband standard enabling HFC (Hybrid Fiber Cable) systems to deliver fiber-like speeds...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/d3-vs-ds3-bandwidth-choices/
